metadata.case_name: Tata Oil Mills Co. Ltd. v. Workmen

facts.text: Dispute between Tata Oil Mills Co. Ltd. (company) and its workmen over profit bonus for the year 1955-56.
Workmen demanded unconditionally bonus equivalent to four months' wages/salary for employees drawing less than Rs. 500 per mensem.
Company had already paid 2½ months' basic wages as bonus.
Dispute referred to Industrial Tribunal, Bombay by Government of Bombay order dated June 18, 1957 (Reference No. T. 119 of 1957).
Company made record profits, declared 12% dividend free of income-tax.
Workmen claimed wages less than living wage, dearness allowance insufficient.
Company paying graded scale of wages with increments, started 1917, shareholders got dividends from 1940.
Company claimed available surplus per Full Bench formula did not justify more than 2½ months bonus.

Company claimed exclusion of six items of extraneous income totaling Rs. 4.12 lacs: rent/light/power (0.24), estate revenue (0.08), profit on empty barrels (0.89), excess provision prior year (0.31), refund income-tax/EPT (0.49), sale proceeds tin cans/scraps etc. (2.11).
Profit of Rs. 3 lacs due to change in method of valuation of assets.
Company claimed 4% interest on working capital including depreciation fund.
Industrial Tribunal disallowed company's claims on extraneous income, Rs. 3 lacs profit, and full working capital; awarded 3½ months bonus.
Workmen conceded exclusion of excess provision (item iv, 0.31) and refund income-tax (item v, 0.49) before Tribunal, but Tribunal overlooked.
Company used reserves including depreciation reserve (total working capital Rs. 139.09 lacs) as per affidavit of Chief Accountant, unchallenged.
Tribunal allowed 4% on working capital of Rs. 31.88 lacs, excluding depreciation reserve.

legal_issues.text: Whether specified items of income (rent/light/power, estate revenue, profit on empty barrels, sale proceeds of scraps etc.) qualify as extraneous income unrelated to labour efforts and excludable from gross profits under Full Bench formula.
Whether profit of Rs. 3 lacs from change in method of valuation of assets is extraneous income.
Whether company entitled to 4% return on full working capital of Rs. 139.09 lacs including depreciation reserve.
Whether available surplus per Full Bench formula justifies bonus beyond 2½ months already paid.

petitioner_arguments.text: Available surplus per Full Bench formula does not justify more than 2½ months bonus already paid.
Six items totaling Rs. 4.12 lacs are extraneous income unrelated to labour efforts and should be excluded.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Precedents from industrial tribunals and Labour Appellate Tribunal

petitioner_arguments.text: Profit of Rs. 3 lacs from change in valuation method not real profit due to labour efforts.
Entitled to 4% interest on working capital including depreciation reserve (Rs. 139.09 lacs) per affidavit.

respondent_arguments.text: Company made record profits, declared 12% dividend; workmen entitled to 4 months bonus as wages below living wage.
Items of income form part of profits earned in course of business; no good reason to deduct as extraneous.
Conceded exclusion of excess provision (0.31 lacs) and income-tax refund (0.49 lacs).

court_reasoning.text: Extraneous income excludable if not earned in that year, from fortuitous circumstances unconnected to labour, or from sale of fixed assets; otherwise, income in normal course of business included even without direct labour connection.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Must be contribution of workmen in earning profits for bonus, but not requiring direct connection for normal business income.

court_reasoning.text: Rent/light/power, estate revenue (coconut sales), profit on empty barrels, sale proceeds scraps etc. arise in normal course of business; expenses met from profits attributable to labour; cannot exclude while deducting related expenses.
court_reasoning.key_observation: These items rightly included by Tribunal.

court_reasoning.text: Rs. 3 lacs profit from valuation change is fortuitous, unconnected to labour, not normal business income; exclude as extraneous.
4% return allowed on full working capital Rs. 139.09 lacs including depreciation reserve per unchallenged affidavit; basis is avoided borrowing interest.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Tribunal erred in excluding depreciation reserve without reason.

court_reasoning.text: Recalculated available surplus Rs. 7.63 lacs; company paid Rs. 7.90 lacs bonus (net Rs. 4.50 lacs after rebate); leaves Rs. 3.13 lacs; more than half to labour; no case for more, especially no rehabilitation claimed.

holdings.text: Four items (rent/light/power, estate revenue, barrels, scraps) not extraneous; include in gross profits.
Rs. 3 lacs valuation profit extraneous; exclude.
Allow 4% on full Rs. 139.09 lacs working capital including depreciation reserve.
No available surplus justifies bonus beyond 2½ months already paid.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mill-Owners Association, Bombay v. The Rashtriya Mill Mazdoor Sangh, Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: Evolved Full Bench formula; extraneous income unrelated to employees' efforts excluded.

precedents_cited.case_name: Shalimar Rope Works Mazdoor Union, Howrah v. Messrs. Shalimar Rope Works Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Profits unrelated to workers' efforts are extraneous and excluded from available surplus.

precedents_cited.case_name: Muir Mills Co. Ltd. v. Suti Mills Mazdoor Union, Kanpur
precedents_cited.relevance: Bonus justified if wages short of living standard and profits due to joint contribution of capital/labour; not directly on extraneous income.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; Industrial Tribunal award set aside; workmen claim for bonus beyond 2½ months already paid dismissed.
outcome.relief_granted: None additional to company; retains 2½ months bonus paid.

key_quotes.text: "No scheme of allocation of bonus could be complete if the amount out of which a bonus is to be paid is unrelated to employees efforts."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From Mill-Owners case; basis for excluding extraneous income.

key_quotes.text: "There must be contribution of the workmen in earning profits before they are entitled to profit bonus."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Clarifies Muir Mills principle; no need for direct connection in normal business income.

key_quotes.text: "This income of Rs. 3 lacs has nothing whatsoever to do with the efforts of labour... must be treated as extraneous income."
key_quotes.speaker: court
